okay there we go so I want to talk briefly about like why why I was excited
about it so I've been working for years on um a product in VMware called vsphere
integrated containers and we came up with this idea of a virtual container host and a virtual container host is
kind of different to a an actor ual container Host this was back in the docker days when all we thought about was a single host um in that it's not a
VM it's not like this static thing that you deploy containers into it's just an
abstract concept it's like this resource limit into which you can deploy any number of containers but if you don't
deploy any containers you don't consume any resource and so we came up with this idea of a virtual container host and the
way that it worked is there was just a simple API endpoint that would run in a vsphere cluster do I have a pointer here
no I don't think oh there we go yeah little API m point that would run in a vsphere cluster and this was what you
would connect to with the docker client and the virtual container host was just this abstract resource limit and when
you wanted to deploy a container the vsphere scheduler would take over and it would figure out which host to put your
container on and then if it wanted to live migrate those containers around it could do that completely transparently
to the client the client just sees a host a single thing but actually behind
the scenes there's many hosts and there's all sorts of other interesting and useful things happening and this is a very useful parallel for
the way that virtual kuet is designed to work so this is just scraped from the virtual kuet uh readme uh in the git uh
in the GitHub repo uh I highly recommend going and kind of looking at at some of the uh information in there because
there's some there's some good data in there um the idea of virtual kuet though is very similar to this idea of the
virtual container host that I just uh referred to in that it allows us to think about resource container resource
pod resource in the abstract a virtual kuet is not a literal VM it's not a literal computer that uh runs containers
it is a this concept of of an abstract resource constraint into which pods and containers can be deployed in some place
so virtual kuet in theory gives you a lot of flexibility in how you uh not only manifest your containers but also
the the resource um uh that your containers use and indeed as well like
we've seen in ACI the way that you pay for your containers so let's delve into this in a little bit more depth so
kubernetes fundamentally is a node-based scheduling system that's what it is and that's what it does it needs nodes it
will always need nodes because the node is the fundamental building block of a cluster obviously and then the Pod is
the building block within the node and containers are little building blocks within the pods but in a node we have a
lot of conventions that we've come to accept in terms of how nodes work and here's a list uh that may be kind of
obvious to people but I think are worth thinking about in terms of the fact that they don't necessarily all have to be
true in order for you to actually just run a container and have a schedule or deploy it things like for example oh all
the pods run in the same address space or you know that the pods share a kernel
or that the node is uh necessarily a static size or you know that a privileged container has to be able to
see all of the resources of everything else on the Node I mean these are all conventions and some of these things
actually I'm sure a part of the kubernetes compliance um but this is how we've come to think of a node and and
just because this is how a node is today doesn't mean that we can't be a little bit more flexible in terms of how we
think about it to get business uh to get business uh value out of
kubernetes so I'm going to dive a little deeper This was um um a diagram that we
did when we were looking at kuet kind of early on in the uh in the virtual kuet project we wanted to say to ourselves
okay well what functionally does kuet do like what is kuet um and we kind of I
actually went through all the code and the net result of all of that was this one slide um which very succinctly
explains what kuet is and what it does kuet fundamentally is a node agent its job is to uh it has two fundamental jobs
one is to manage and configure the node make sure that it's um you know it's
it's all the resources in the node are being correctly um uh apportioned to to pods and containers and images and
Emeral storage and all these other things the second job that it has is pil and container life cycle management so
the things like um you know starting containers um init containers um uh
liveness and redness um um checks all these all these other things now the way
that kuet works is it has two paths uh two control paths one is the
asynchronous path which you see on the left here which is a polling based mechanism and it's actually interesting because if you go to kuet and look for
an API there isn't like a big API in kuet there's not like a start pod API in
kuet for example it it doesn't do it quite that way it has this polling side of the fence which handles all the
things like um you know basically the life cycle of any kubernetes object and turns that into things like creating and
mounting volume well mounting volumes um um you know Secrets um configuring the
host for DNS um you know updating a pod starting a pod stopping a pod all of these things are handled by that
asynchronous side on the left on the right hand side we have the synchronous path which is all of the interaction
that you might have with the container via Cube cuttle so if you want to uh get a shell for example into a container or
run a process in it or get logs from it that's a synchronous path that goes through this uh this this channel on the
right hand side and you can see uh some of the high level function that that kuet handles down there in the bottom
right now kuet also has its own internal control loops so things like garbage
collection making sure that uh pods are evicted if it starts getting low on resources um as I mentioned the liveness
and redness probes um so this is kind of from a very high level perspective what kuet is and what it does so approaching
this from the perspective of virtual kuet you kind of have to ask yourself well okay if we're creating this this
virtual node um that the kubernetes master is going to interact with if it's
going to look and feel and smell and behave just like a regular node we need to make sure that we uh that we um
provide both the polling mechanisms that are consistent with kuet and the synchronous path that's consistent with
kuet so that it will function in the same way so let's talk in a little bit more
depth in about virtual kuet and and what the point is now I want to just stress the point of virtual kuet is not to uh
replace regular kuet it's not as as a it's not designed to be a groundup uh re
architecture or groundup refactoring of kuet it's not that at all it's it's a kubernetes client uh that aims to
represent a different kind of resource than just a regular kubernetes node um
so we talked earlier that a virtual kubet the whole point of it is that it allows us to be a little bit more
flexible about how we think about nodes and pods so it allows us to think about them more in the abstract than in the
literal way we think about them in a vanilla kubernetes node so node rather than being this thing with a kuet in it
this operating system running a kuet with container D or whatever else is in there um it's just a bounded amount of
resource that can run pods that is the definition of a virtual kuet node quote unquote and a pod of course is a set of
containers that are running within a sandbox but the way that a Sandbox is is
manifested can be something that's quite flexible because virtual kubet is not opinionated about that so when you get
into those specifics about what a container is what a pot is uh how you do garbage collection how you do image
management all these other things all of that is encapsulated inside of a thing called a provider which uh which which
which is a pluggable interface in Virtual kuet that allows different um uh
different instantiation of this virtual node concept to be to be executed and I think there's something
like 10 is it 10 providers in the virtual 12 okay there's quite a few providers in in the virtual kuet GitHub
repo now uh there's one for fargate there's one for ACI uh there's there's a bunch of them in
there um and it's interesting to note that actually you know if we go back to this this previous slide like the things
that you really need here that are common to every single provider is mostly the stuff in this box on the left
hand side the polling mechanism the event handling um and the stuff on the right hand side that handles the the the
synchronous interaction with containers that's stuff that every single provider is going to need so that's the stuff that's in the core that's in the base
but the base is actually quite small the common code is is a relatively small and simple um uh code base and much of the
complexity is intentionally left up to the provider to deal with and the interface is exactly what you would
expect it to be it is get pod uh stop pod uh start pod right it's all written
in terms of this pod concept that you're then as a provider left up to to implement and and and be specific
about so and it's worth noting that virtual kuet itself can be deployed as a
pod like everything these days so this whole question of why virtual
kuer I think is a really really important question and Ria's going to delve into that and a lot more when she looks at use cases um but I think it's a
really important question um partly as I as I mentioned because um you know it's
important that it's not seen as something that is necessarily there to replace existing kuet maybe it could be
named a little bit differently but it seemed an appropriate name at the time I'm sure um ultimately it's there uh to
give us flexibility of abstraction um it allows us more potentially more
granularity uh um in terms of uh the way we're deploying things let me give you an example so I was speaking to Alex
Ellis this morning uh he's the creator of open F and he was saying well wouldn't it be really cool if uh we had
like these little iot nodes and um and in each one was a little container engine and we could just deploy
containers or pods into each of these iot nodes and then there's going to be this Edge controller that just kind of controls all the iot nodes well wouldn't
it be cool if we could add that edge controller to a kubernetes cluster and get kubernetes to deploy containers to all these ADOT noes I was like yeah that
would be cool that is exactly the the kind of use case that virtual kuet addresses right it's a non-standard node
idea in that the The Edge controller is not a typical kubernetes node um but the
edge controller can handle the scheduling it can handle you know how containers go to which iot device and rooting and networking and various other
things but you can take a step back from that and then abstract it out and say regardless of how this is all
manifesting we're still thinking about this as a node and we're still thinking about pods and
containers um so here's just four bullet point use cases uh that I'm going to
sort of cover from from a high level perspective before before we hand over to Ria um the hybrid use case is one that uh
Microsoft have been demoing a lot with the ACI connector that they have the hybrid use case is very simply uh I have
an existing kubernetes cluster may be on Prem it may be in AKs it may be he knows
where it is um and I want to have the ability to deploy pods to something that
either I can burst into or that I'm paying like for the Pod not for the node
right because ACI offers you the ability to pay for containers that are running and pay for pods that are running the
moment you shut them down you're not paying for them anymore which is a very very flexible way to pay for things well this one node can represent that portal
into into uh ACI and theoretically infinite resource right so it allows
your one cluster to have this kind of special magic portal sounds like a children's book doesn't it maybe we
should write one um for containers and pods to go into into ACI and be deployed
there so that's the hybrid use case um an interesting other use case case that
I haven't actually seen yet but I think would be uh would be worth uh experimenting with is one in which you
you put a virtual kubl in each availability zone so you might have a cloud and you know you have um you know
virtual kuet that represents post deployed in one availability Zone and and you may may have any number of
availability zones and then you add those to a single kubernetes cluster that can then deploy pods across
availability zones well that's kind of cool because you then keep this notion of affinity anti- Affinity so you can
make sure that your um your replica set is deployed across availability zones um
without but with just a single cluster single Schuler so that would be kind of a cool idea and I mentioned the iot use
case um and then you know any any use case really where you have a node that
really doesn't conform to the way that kuet expects things to be virtual kuet
uh could be a solution for you so uh I have uh a minute before I'm handing over to to Ria I don't want to skip over this
because compatibility challenges is such an important question it's one that a lot of people immediately uh want to ask
questions about so I've laid out what I think are the the most significant compatibility challenges of virtual kuet
um and the first point to make here is that that when pods are deployed to a
special node a virtual kuet node you have to want that to happen it's not something that's just going to happen
automatically you have to specifically say okay this node is special I'm giving it this taint and and I want particular
uh pods to be deployed to that node so that's how how you might use it um now in some of these use
cases um a a virtual kuet could represent multiple fault domains in which case the whole notion of affinity
and anti-affinity um um becomes a difficult one to to to to to to to wrestle with because it's just a single
node right so it um in the case where we have multiple nodes in multiple availability zones again you know you
sort of you can think about those fault domains and you can get that capability back but it doesn't always map one to
one as cleanly as a regular node would in a kubernetes cluster if that makes sense to people um now of course
privilege containers can't you can't guarantee that they're going to get access to an ABI and get access to uh
the resources of a node because there is maybe there maybe is no node right there probably is a node somewhere but you
know your privileged container is not necessarily going to get you access to that node um um another one is um that
when you deploy pods in a node there's quite a bit of configuration that they inherit uh from that node either because
the node has a um uh a volume like maybe secrets are going to be written to a volume and you update the secret and
automatically because the volume is bind mounted into a container the container gets to see that updated secret right
it's inheriting that state from the node um in Virtual kubet again you can't guarantee that um because there may be
no node or the node may be distributed so a notion of actually being able to push things to pods rather than pods
inheriting uh a config is is something that's been built into virtual kuet and of course the provider itself has to um
uh either either Implement a lot of function to deal with all of these things like image management volume
management um either you know the either you're going to rely on on a on a KU another kubernetes cluster somewhere or
you're going to have something else that does that for you um but that's these are these are the high level compatibility challenges that uh that we
confront with uh with virtual kuet I think that is uh yeah that's the last of my slid so I'm going to hand over to Ria

on the Fly we can spin out just c um containers to customers on demand so

kubernetes to this unbounded resource toci so it's a completely different service

when I was born and then we built virtual koet because we realized that this was a problem and this was

case that we talk about all the time um but basically you have your normal

looks like a node but there's no resources that are backed by it it's literally just a string in when you say
C cuddle get nodes it's just a string and it kind of looks like a node to you anytime you spin out a pod to that node
